body: Looks like solid work to me. Any chances of getting this merged? What's stopping it?

@danielepolencic Yes. I've got it working. The reference project to get it running is here: https://github.com/heroku/heroku-airflow

Unfortunately, I haven't had time to document it and how to get started. The process is a little contrived because Heroku Button doesn't work for our new docker based workflow (https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/docker) which makes it a little hard to get started.
Gamechanger.

I have a weekly job that bulk loads some data. My understanding of the scheduler is that if I have a schedule interval of a week, once that week has elapsed and the scheduler kicks off the dag, I'll see 7 sequential executions (if `depends_on_past=True`).

This isn't the functionality I need - I'd like one dag run per week and dont even use the execution date parameter in my dag. Is this a solid case for `only_run_latest` or have I misunderstood the function? Is there a way I can achieve this prior to the feature being implemented using some sort of hack within my dag?

@puckel I'm wondering if the way I did it might fix it for you:  https://github.com/heroku/heroku-airflow/blob/master/airflow.cfg

I did have to pin airflow to a commit past the 1.5.1 release to get this to work.
+1 would love to see this merged

I'm pinning the versions because these libs might eventually break their APIs, sometimes on purpose. Actually what prompted the pinning was flask-login breaking their API on purpose (for pretty much everyone using their lib) and when I posted on their Github they told me that they thought it was absolutely insane to not systematically pin everything. 

My current logic is to trust the package maintainers to not break the API within big version numbers after 1.0.0 and second digit before 1.0.0, so I enable a range from what I use to run unit tests to the next version number where the API might change.

Oh nice. Actually it'd be nice if it matched the standard python `get` method's positional args as in

```
>>> {'foo': 'bar'}.get('foo2', 'default')
'default'
```

Though if anyone used session as a positional arg it would fail but I don't think that's a concern.

What about changing from:
`def get(cls, key, session, deserialize_json=False, default_var=None):`
to 
`def get(cls, key, default_var=None, session=None, deserialize_json=False):`

?
I'm running the unit tests against it now and merging as soon as it passes
Thank you for this major contribution!

I think it's unrelated, it sounds to me like you need a DAG with a `schedule_interval=timedelta(7)`. The tasks in there will get executed once a week.

Only run latest would mean that if task a depends on task b, and task b fails for 10 days an recover after, task a will only run that last day. Also tasks depending on task a will have a that dependency satisfied for all days up until the latest run.

I'm not sure if the libs we use do support Windows, but if they do it seems like it may not be too hard to support windows. Well I mean for Airflow to be retrofitted to work on windows. It's probably mostly a matter of making sure all file references use `os.path.join` instead of  `FOLDER + "/foo"`.

Though there may be more to it, I haven't touched a Windows server since NT4. I tried to SSH in one for Tableau one time and was told that you couldn't do that.

Airbnb won't be driving Windows support but if someone from the community wants to send PRs in that direction we'll be happy to review / merge them.

Yes, default_var after key is nice, but initially I wanted to break as little as possible. In new commit:

Changed order of arguments, also deserialize_json goes after default_var, in case you are super lazy and wants to use something like 

```
foo = Variable.get('bar', '{"baz": "qux"}', True)
```

More informative error message.  'NoneType' object has no attribute 'val' is not transparent enough. Now 

```
>>> Variable.get('bar')
ERROR - Variable bar does not exist
```

I've been playing with this by having a start date of September 1st and `schedule_interval=timedelta(7)`. When running the scheduler for the first time I saw a backfill over this date range - i.e. multiple task runs, one for each day that has elapsed.

What I'd actually like is one task run (rather than a months worth), as its inefficient for my process to run multiple times. Is there not a way of either marking the dag as success or skipping an execution if the rundate isn't the maximum possible rundate? I guess the first scenario I describe is when the dag is seeded, but how about if my host has problems and my dag fails to run for a month? I'd like to see a single dag execution in this scenario.

Some things that I have in mind (and might even work on :-) ):
1. Continous Integration - I would like airflow to integrate with something like travis-ci, circle-ci, gitlab-ci. This would make submitting patches a breeze and I assume it would make reviewing easier as well. I have already done some work on this in my travisci branch in https://github.com/bolkedebruin/airflow, but it is still in the early stages. I am using snakebite's integration testing as an example as they include testing against hadoop and multiple python's.
2. Now that basic kerberos is in (thanks!), I would like to have integration with a LDAP directory and role based access. I have kerberos and ldap (yes both) web authentication ready (not quite ready for merging yet). A change here I would suggest to airflow is to make the login handler configurable instead of doing this by PYTHON_PATH.
3. HDFS DAG Storage - No need for syncing directories any more and it helps closing the loop from a security perspective. Arguably this can be quite a task to achieve due to the fact that snakebite does not support python 3 yet and the alternative libhdfs3 has no python integration yet.
4. YARN executor - No need anymore for a separate cluster just run it in the hadoop eco system. Spark comes to mind how to handle this (maybe).

Thanks! This worked like a charm. All we had to do is to drop that py-file into plugins folder! Great!

B.R.,
Mikko

From: Rimas Silkaitis [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: 30. syyskuuta 2015 18:38
To: airbnb/airflow airflow@noreply.github.com
Cc: Kivistö Mikko Mikko.Kivisto@fonecta.com
Subject: Re: [airflow] Question with using Airflow with HTTPS (#373)

I did some work on this and it comes down to the url scheme in flask. If you can redirect to that and your whatever you're using to proxy requests ELB in this case uses X-Forwarded-Proto in the headers, then this is fixable.

This gist (https://gist.github.com/neovintage/d93baefc7f623a8f599f) is a plugin that you can add to your installation to add SSL support. Ideally, this should really be merged into master and a config option added. We don't want passwords and things flying over the wire in plain text.

If @mistercrunchhttps://github.com/mistercrunch thinks it's worthwhile, I can create a pull request instead of this being a plugin.

We can prob close this issue out too.

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/373#issuecomment-144449599.
Also, `airflow test ep_demo purge_DLQ 2015-10-07` works but `airflow run ep_demo purge_DLQ 2015-10-07` fails!

Thinking about `depends_on_past` and `wait_for_downstream`, it would be better to represent those as dependencies, similar to the way we set upstream tasks normally. So, just as we would set t2 as dependent on t1 by doing `t2.set_upstream(t1)`, we could say t2 should wait for its previous run to finish by setting `t2.set_yesterday_as_upstream(t2)`. Then you get functionality like `wait_for_downstream` for free, eg `t1.set_yesterday_as_upstream(t2)`.  And it would unify the conceptual image between `set_upstream` and `depends_on_past` to both just being arrows.

There's a common thread here, of taking all the logic that dictates how the DAG is followed, and putting it into the DAG itself. On this thread, it might pay to do the same with `trigger_rule`. Instead of specifying on the task level how to join the upstream tasks, have separate nodes which would be e.g. `or` nodes (where `or` means "go as soon as one upstream has finished/succeeded"), or an `is_finished` node. (`and` and `was_success` would be the default so that you don't have to add nodes everywhere).  Then you could do more advanced dependencies like "Run t3 if t1 successfully completes or if t2 completes at all"

Here's how these two ideas would look conceptually
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4633429/10346559/df31f9a8-6cfd-11e5-9d9d-ca976b99ca70.png)

Note that you could probably mimic most of the functionality of the `trigger_rule` "logic" nodes (all but the `not` node, I believe) by just creating a dummy task and setting the appropriate `trigger_rule` on that task. But that would store its results in the database and appear in all the visualizations, which is probably not desirable.

That's odd, in theory, the code at https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/S3_hook.py#L140-L152 should get a new token each time. I am afraid I might be out of my depth on those internals.

The S3 hook is due for a redesign especially using boto3. If anybody wants to volunteer... :smile:

We don't use any AWS airflow hooks - we only use the Python and Bash operator types. Via boto, we call out AWS. Instead, we just use boto2. We don't have any problem running `airflow test`, but this is not working via the local executors at all. We have built a python script named `reload_data.py` that reload a range of days. The script calls into airflow tasks via the CLI using `airflow test`. Right now, we are exclusively using this script. Our airflow server is completely blocked since it uses executors. Any help you can provide would be helpful.

Also, I don't think I need to mention this, but I am able to make calls via boto in a python shell or regular boto program as well. So, it's just a problem with the local executors. I've restarted them.. etc... so I'm really wondering if there is some token caching or something being done.
Ok.. found the issue. A `./aws/credentials` file with a different set of creds. I figured that ENV vars always won.

We found that if we want to have a new start_date, we need to do `airflow clear` first, followed by restarting the scheduler. The scheduler is not aware of the new start_date simply from loading the modified DAG file. Is this expected?
Perfect. Thanks for you contribution!

But when I tried to test with kerberos - I got this:

`File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/snakebite/channel.py", line 236, in get_connection
    sasl = SaslRpcClient(self)`
`NameError: global name 'SaslRpcClient' is not defined`

I double checked and made sure I built pkg with this feature. I also have rpc_sasl.py where SaslRpcClient is defined. What am I missing?

Hi @praveev this is obviously an issue in snakebite and not per se in airflow. Did you install the cyrus-sasl libraries / kerberos flavor of snakebite (ie. does snakebite work from the command line ?)

You can use 

Kinit -kt path/to/keytab <principal>

And then

snakebite ls /

Ok. This is an issue with a change that was done in snakebite to do a conditional import.

If you add:
          from snakebite.rpc_sasl import SaslRpcClien
          from snakebite.kerberos import Kerberos

to the top of snakebite/channel.py it should start working

Can you raise this issue with snakebite?

@mistercrunch Yea, I was planning to add a few more columns to the `BaseUser` model, like `roles` etc.

I think that'd be very useful for everyone. We probably need the following models:
Role (many to many with User)
Permission (many to many with Role)

The list of permissions could be each UI view, and potentially CRUD related for each model (view / modify).

OR a bolder move would be to migrate the application to use a more complete web framework. I've been using "Flask App Builder" for another project and I love it. It ships with CRUD, authentication, security, localization, bootstrap, charts, icons, ... It's a better fit for Airflow than Flask-Admin (the current CRUD framework Airflow uses).
http://flask-appbuilder.readthedocs.org/en/latest/

I don't think it would be extremely hard to migrate since they're built on the same stack (Flask / Jinja / Bootstrap, ....)

Nice! `Flask App Builder` looks pretty good. I'd love to take a stab at it to have 1) a richer BaseUser model 2) some layer of web auth (currently I modified `default_login` to work with Google oauth2 for security).
Porting to FAB might be easy, I'll try to find time to take a stab at it.

Sorry for hijacking this thread but I thought I'd drop this here in case anyone else has the same requirement or I'm doing something insane (likely).

As my job is weekly and is a bulk process that cant be incrementally run using 7 dag executions, I've used the `PythonBranchOperator` to skip certain dag runs. Essentially I check `{ds}` when the dag is kicked off and branch to a `DummyOperator` if `{ds}` isnt yesterdays date. This means my weekly dag is has 6 dummy runs and 1 logical run when its scheduled.

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/622988b1fc17abf5fa3e5b36269097ce424b0f04

Actually, this extension of BashOperator was made because I didn't know how to pass jinja parameters to underlying (non-bash) script. After some googling though, it looks like it can be done with something like 

```
cmd = '''
cat > test.rb <<EOF
puts '{{ ds }}'
EOF

ruby test.rb
'''

t1 = BashOperator(
bash_command=cmd,
...
)
```

It's not very nice looking, and not very obvious solution, but it is working, so, yes, ShebangOperator is not needed. May be you can add something like 'cookbook' or 'best practices' on pythonhosted documentation? Snippets like this can be time savers.
@kkourtchikov, can you confirm that this works on your side?

`requirements.txt` doesn't do much for projects on Pypi. The dependencies for Airflow (and all projects on Pypi) are defined using setuptools, typically in a `setup.py` 
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/setup.py#L50

Quite a bit of thoughts went into dependencies specifications for Airflow. Fully freezing versions (as opposed to allowing ranges as it is currently) has downsides as we might miss out on security updates and bugfixes, also you might have to download multiple versions of each library to satisfy each project (you can end up with 6 versions of pandas/numpy on your system which isn't great). On the other hand there could be bugs in the community that others can't recreate which isn't great. 

I'm giving the current method a spin and if I get bit I might fully freeze.
I've never seen a deadlock on Airflow. Which database are you using? How many tasks do you have running? What kind of interval? How big are your payloads?

I think I'd rather log `current_user.username` into owner.

Another option to limit the log would be to log a single call per user action (as opposed to the whole list of affected tasks). We should throw a blob field in this table to allow for arbitrary k/v pairs and log the params (date range, task regexp, ...) used. Seems to be a very good use case for a function decorator. We should probably sprinkle some of this all over the scheduler as well.

I'm using MariaDB 10.0.20 on ubuntu 15.04. I've had one script that made 10 DAGs(different IDes but the same structure, with 4 tasks) and it was the first task that fails than everything was smooth.
Is it possible to put different hooks/operators/macros in different directories instead of in one file?
@Yongyiw , yes, totally. Within your main plugin file you can import other python modules and associate their content to your `AirflowPlugin`

@mistercrunch It works for me. Thanks a lot! 

For future convenience, what i have done is 

1) Created empty files named `__init__.py` in `plugins` directory and its sub-directories eg. `hooks`, `operators`, etc.... 

2) In `AirflowPlugin` type: 

```
     from hooks.your_customized_hook import YourCustomizedHook
     from operators.your_customized_operator import YourCustomizedOperator
```

Details about [python-how-to-import-the-class-within-the-same-directory-or-sub-directory](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4142151/python-how-to-import-the-class-within-the-same-directory-or-sub-directory)

Somewhat unrelated: I've been planning on allowing for the scheduler to be distributable (many scheduler instances running concurrently). It would be a matter of taking locks in DagModel, adding a `DAG.schedule_frequency` param and looking at `DagModel.last_run` to sort on which DAG should be processed first. Maybe a way to identify old dead lock and autounlock a DAG that's been locked for more than say 10 minutes.

You should be able to import scripts or libraries from anywhere on `PATH` just as with any python library; Airflow adds `$AIRFLOW_HOME` to `PATH` (I believe) so a scripts folder there would work. An alternative would be to build a library with its own DAG folder and point (or symlink) the airflow DAG folder at that one.

I believe the only way to avoid rebuilding a Docker container is to use a Docker volume for shared state.
@mistercrunch could you please add a Python 3.4 (or 3.5 :) ) build? That would be extremely helpful for maintaining compatibility.

Installing a python packages (`python setup.py install`, `pip install foo`) add it to your site-packages, which is part of your python path, meaning when you `import foo` it will find it. You can also use the PYTHONPATH environment variable to include arbitrary folders. Another method is to use sys.path, as in:

```
import sys
sys.path.append('/mnt/foo')
```

Note that for a folder to be considered a package it needs a `__init__.py` file in it.

Airflow adds your DAGS_FOLDER to your python path. So provided that you sprinkle `__init__.py` files around your pipelines, you can always do absolute imports from a pipeline to the other.
I've implemented some alerting and common functions I use in my dags. I've packaged them and reference them like @mistercrunch describes using `PYTHONPATH`, works a treat for me!
@jlowin : totally. 3.4 or 3.5? Initially I don't want to put too much stress on travis, so let's just pick one.
I'd vote for starting out cutting edge with 3.5, especially since us Py3-ers seem few and far between :).

Looks like a bug to me.

The `ParseResult` object returned by `urlparse` stores the schema (https) portion of the uri in the `scheme` property, but this field isn't grabbed [in `models.Connection`](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/1.5.1/airflow/models.py#L338).

The [`HttpHook` class](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/1.5.1/airflow/hooks/http_hook.py#L26) builds the url using only the host and the port, including the username and password for basic auth if they were passed.

To fix this, `models.Connection` needs to store the scheme and make that available to `HttpHook` for building the url.

Database values aren't set at runtime (depending on what you mean by that), they're persistent. So it seems like the more ephemeral envvars should have precedence as a way to override them. 

About the configuration file, I'm thinking about eventually moving away from the `.cfg` format and into the `settings.py` file as it's more dynamic and the native lib for cfg parsing is pretty horrible. You could actually today use a `airflow_local_settings.py` in your PYTHONPATH to define connections as a bit of code that uses the Connection model to save connection metadata in the database.
We use chef, so that kind of information is stored in an encrypted chef databag and deployed by chef.

Thanks for getting back @mistercrunch.

The scenario that I'm driving at for database values vs environment variables is this:
- user sets an environment variable for a connection `AIRFLOW_CONN_ELASTICSEARCH` (to serve as a default location)
- user wants to update that connection to point to the new location for elasticsearch without restarting airflow
- they go to the web ui and add a connection `elasticsearch`
- but airflow keeps using the environment variable

Yeah, connection objects are persisted in the database - what I meant was that they can be _changed_ at runtime (bad choice of words on my part).

An example of a tool that takes this approach to configuration is elasticsearch.  You can modify settings via a REST api and those are persisted (technically, they are optionally persisted) between restarts of the application.

About the configuration file, I guess that makes sense.  I saw [that hook](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/1.5.1/airflow/settings.py#L69) today when looking at the code and wasn't sure what the recommended use of that is.  Using it to inject more content into the settings django-style makes sense.  Thanks for the tip.

About the switch from cfg: I can tell you that a lot of tools out there are moving to yaml, toml, or even json since they are more friendly to edit in other languages than python files.  At my company we just moved a few internal services off of python files for that reason (and also the need to play with the python path to get those formats to work).  I agree that cfg files are not super awesome.

@mistercrunch @artwr I have a reasonable test environment running now (my own branch). 

I have used caching for dependencies by using wheels and by storing them in travis cache. Missing dependencies get added automatically, upgrades of packages not. This speeds up testing from +30mins to around 2mins. Further caching can be done on the hadoop components if required.

Todo: 
- Invalidate cache in case of requirements that need to be upgraded
- The file matching does not entirely work, don't know how to improve currently. Better matching means faster tests
- Selective testing for things that can be tested in travis
- Have an initial mysql / postgres db

Please have a look. The commits are messy at the moment due to a lot of trial and error (geez!)
